p: Insect vectors such as mosquitoes and biting flies ( Culicoides spp.) are often responsible for the transmission of bunyaviruses associated with human and animal diseases in Asia and Africa. Immediately after the discovery of SBV, it became evident that Culicoides spp. play a role in its transmission [ 25]. SBV genomic sequences were detected in biting flies, namely the Culicoides obsoletus species group of the Ceratopogonidae family, and it was shown that multiple Culicoides spp. ( Culicoides dewulfi, Culicoides chiopterus, Culicoides punctatus, etc) were positive for SBV genomic markers. Culicoides caught as early as summer and autumn of 2011 in Belgium [ 26], Italy [ 27], The Netherlands [ 28], and Denmark [ 25] were found positive for SBV genomic markers. Interestingly, Culicoides sonorensis, a vector for BTV, was also shown to support the replication and dissemination of SBV under laboratory conditions [ 29]. The question of how the vector-borne SBV persists over winter has not been solved yet; however, one field study has demonstrated that the potential mechanism is transovarial transmission in the Culicoides vector [ 30].
